references: In this section, we describe the backbone of the proposed framework in detail. Our description mainly focuses on a building with multiple
where there exist various heterogeneous CIoT devices inside

. Although designed for a smart building, the model can be readily interpreted as a general-purpose framework for other fields of intelligent environment and devices such as smart factories, smart cities, and smart indoor environments
provide the summary of the notations used hereafter.
In this work, we consider a smart building consisting of
smart homes each equipped with a Femto Access Point (FAP). Each smart home includes
, and with the total number of
devices. For simplicity and without loss of generality, we assume all devices belonging to a smart home are inside a single room. Each room, also called a cluster, is indexed by

We opt to select devices that are prevalent in real-world scenarios and mostly present in every common living room. To illustrate a more realistic scenario, consider each room having a set of common CIoT devices such as laptops, smartphones, smartwatches, tablets, and a smart TV creating a heterogeneous setup. In this case, each device
is capable of performing a complex computation while having different specifications.
is connected to its neighbors in the subset
. It is assumed that devices in the building constitute a bidirectional graph, denoted by
consists of all devices as the vertices of the graph and
indicates all the edges connecting the devices. Moreover, the weight of the edges is indicated in the adjacency matrix
is the connection weight of devices
is chosen as either â€œoneâ€ or â€œzeroâ€ indicating the connectivity of devices

denotes the maximum distance considered for paired devices. In addition, all devices have access to a nearby edge server to where they can share information and exchange data. The edge server can be any high processing machine located in the building, such as a central computer. It should be noted that the point of considering the graph connectivity between devices is to exploit such relationship and flow of information among devices which will be elaborated on further in the paper.
, has a local dataset, denoted by
, might or not have shared data samples. In this scheme, a supervised training procedure is considered where
represents the total number of data samples in
specifies the feature space of the input data
, distributed among devices in the set
, represents the parameters to be trained. Hence, the loss function of device
denotes the cardinality of the set
. The collaborative loss function of the framework is calculated as
is the associated weight of each device

.
The main goal of the FL is to solve the following minimization problem:
is the optimum parameter weights for the model
. Note that in case of searching a global parameter, we have

In case the input dimensions of ML models are different, one can equalize the dimensions using Encoder-Decoder (En-De) architectures. To do so, a preprocessing En-De unit can be used before the ML model of each device

. Although En-De units are fed with different input dimensions, they can produce fixed-size latent spaces. Finally, the ML models are fed by the acquired latent space features that have the same dimensions.

references: The underlying concept of using graph filters in G-Fedfilt is to consider both the domain-specific and the domain-agnostic gradient updates; to have a tunable personalization in FL. In this regard, we propose a graph filter operator in the graph frequency domain, behaving as a low-pass filter, that could achieve such a goal which is expressed as follows:
is the tunable parameter of the filter. Therefore, given the eigenvalue
is to attenuate the coefficients in
associated with higher frequencies while retaining the coefficients related to lower frequencies. This can be accomplished by the multiplication

.
An illustration of such a filter is shown in Fig.

has a smooth transient low-pass filter which eventually goes to zero. It is worthwhile to remind that graph frequencies are represented by the eigenvalues of the graph Laplacian and therefore, vary with respect to

symmetric matrix and the silver-colored horizontal lines show the eigenvalues of such matrix, i.e., graph frequencies ordered from zero to the highest eigenvalue corresponding to the highest graph frequency. Note that, the filter

is not ideal and in fact, there are many ways to design a more suitable filter to be used in G-Fedfilt which opens up lots of rooms to design graph filters for the purpose of better aggregation in the GFIoTL.
To have a better understanding of a low-pass graph filtering application, a graph signal along with its corresponding filtered versions is illustrated in Fig.
. We used the publicly available PyGSP toolbox for this simulationÂ
devices interconnected via a graph as a simulation environment of a building with multiple
is expressed with a color representing the first gradient element
shared with all devices. From this figure, it is seen that when the graph is filtered with
, the average of the gradients will be calculated whereas, when filtered with

, they have different aggregated values, though, they are still very close to the average. This behavior indicates that there is a flow of information among devices, and there also exists a level of personalization that can be smoothly controlled by adjusting the tunable parameter, i.e.,
. Another salient point worth discussing is that when the graph is filtered by

, each section of the graph appears to have a certain aggregated gradient value; as if each section turned into a cluster where the gradient value assigned to the nodes is the average value of that particular cluster. This behavior suggests that graph filtering can indeed cluster devices dynamically and intrinsically solely based on the graphâ€™s connectivity. In the end, a filter such as

behaves as an all-pass filter where the local updates will be assigned as the next gradient updated without considering the neighboring gradients. The proposed G-Fedfilt algorithm is shown in Algorithm

references: Furthermore, we presume a deterministic graph structure ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathcal{G} in the experiments illustrated in Fig. 5. Note that the graph frequencies of ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathcal{G} are the horizontal lines shown in Fig. 2. In particular, there are 202020 eigenvalues each corresponding to the graph frequencies where the first one with the value 00 indicates the DC and the last one with the value 8.068.068.06 corresponds to the highest graph frequency in ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathcal{G}. Furthermore, we assume full participation where all devices share their models at each communication round. We also set Î±si,cj=3subscriptğ›¼subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—3\alpha_{s_{i,c_{j}}}=3 for the device-based number of iterations in all our experiments, except in the parameter optimization simulation. The whole parameter specifications are gathered in Table 3 for convenience.

Communication Desynchronization Alleviation:
In this simulation, we investigate the effect of dynamic values for Ïˆâ€‹(ğ’Ÿsi,cj;qsi,cj)ğœ“subscriptğ’Ÿsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—\psi(\mathcal{D}_{s_{i,c_{j}}};q_{s_{i,c_{j}}}) and Ï‡â€‹(Ï†â€‹(ğ’ˆsi,cj;zsi,cj))ğœ’ğœ‘subscriptğ’ˆsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğ‘§subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—\chi(\varphi(\boldsymbol{g}_{s_{i,c_{j}}};z_{s_{i,c_{j}}})) on the communication desynchronization and latency when the control parameters zsi,cjsubscriptğ‘§subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—z_{s_{i,c_{j}}}, qsi,cjsubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—q_{s_{i,c_{j}}}, and Î±si,cjsubscriptğ›¼subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—\alpha_{s_{i,c_{j}}} are optimized based on solving problem ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}. We set Î¼1=Î¼2=0.4subscriptğœ‡1subscriptğœ‡20.4\mu_{1}=\mu_{2}=0.4 and Î¼3=0.2subscriptğœ‡30.2\mu_{3}=0.2 for solving the optimization problem in the simulation where Î¼1+Î¼2+Î¼3=1subscriptğœ‡1subscriptğœ‡2subscriptğœ‡31\mu_{1}+\mu_{2}+\mu_{3}=1. Note that the reason for selecting a smaller Î¼3subscriptğœ‡3\mu_{3} lies behind the fact that it is experimentally shown in (Aji and Heafield, 2017), that almost 90%percent9090\% of the gradients to be sent to the server can be ignored with nearly no loss of classification accuracy. In addition, maximizing Ïˆâ€‹(ğ’Ÿsi,cj;qsi,cj)ğœ“subscriptğ’Ÿsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—\psi(\mathcal{D}_{s_{i,c_{j}}};q_{s_{i,c_{j}}}) and Î±si,cjsubscriptğ›¼subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—\alpha_{s_{i,c_{j}}} participate more to higher classification accuracy compared to that of zsi,cjsubscriptğ‘§subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—z_{s_{i,c_{j}}} which corresponds to decreasing the sparsification. We further opt to select bsi,cj=Î²Ksubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—ğ›½ğ¾b_{s_{i,c_{j}}}=\frac{\beta}{K}, qsi,cjmin=0.3superscriptsubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—min0.3q_{s_{i,c_{j}}}^{\textrm{min}}=0.3, Î±si,cjmin=1superscriptsubscriptğ›¼subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—min1\alpha_{s_{i,c_{j}}}^{\textrm{min}}=1, Î±si,cjmax=5superscriptsubscriptğ›¼subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—max5\alpha_{s_{i,c_{j}}}^{\textrm{max}}=5, and zsi,cjmin=0.1superscriptsubscriptğ‘§subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—min0.1z_{s_{i,c_{j}}}^{\textrm{min}}=0.1, âˆ€si,cjâˆˆğ’¦cjfor-allsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğ’¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘—\forall s_{i,c_{j}}\in\mathcal{K}_{c_{j}}, for simplicity and to have a minimum convergence requirement for the training process. Thus, after the optimization, the number of data samples for training and the sparsified gradients required to be sent to the server is obtained for each device. We determine different heterogeneous settings, indicated by Hğ»H, by producing random values for simulation parameters specified in Table 3. The performance of the proposed G-Fedfilt algorithm with Î¼s=10subscriptğœ‡ğ‘ 10\mu_{s}=10 is evaluated in Table 7 before and after the framework is optimized for different Hğ»H. Moreover, the models are trained on MNIST10 dataset and evaluated on its global test set. After 200200200 communication rounds, we can observe that there is a 99.63%percent99.6399.63\% and 47.91%percent47.9147.91\% reduction in the total communication desynchronization and latency when comparing G-FedfiltOpt with G-Fedfilt for H=0.31ğ»0.31H=0.31; although, it costs 2.14%percent2.142.14\% accuracy reduction. It is also seen that when Hğ»H increases, the desynchronization time and the latency are affected less for G-FedfiltOpt than that of G-Fedfilt; however, the accuracy decreases largely. One more important result that can be deduced in Table 7 is that when executing the algorithm for 400400400 communication rounds, the accuracy of G-FedfiltOpt increases at a faster pace than that of G-Fedfilt. This phenomenon is due to the fact that at each round of communication some devices with less computational capabilities train their models with the subset of the true dataset, i.e., ğ’Ÿ^si,cjâŠ†ğ’Ÿsi,cjsubscript^ğ’Ÿsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğ’Ÿsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—\widehat{\mathcal{D}}_{s_{i,c_{j}}}\subseteq\mathcal{D}_{s_{i,c_{j}}}. Thus, G-FedfiltOpt eventually achieves comparable accuracy to G-Fedfilt in the long run. It is worthwhile to note that a larger number of communication rounds does not mean a longer latency. For instance, we can see in Table 7 that G-FedfiltOpt achieves +1%percent1+1\% better accuracy than G-Fedfilt with the fairly similar latency, however, 200200200 more communication rounds. In addition, the bar graph in Fig. 9 shows the computation cost of this simulation under different heterogeneous settings and after 400400400 communication rounds. As observed, the cost of G-Fedfiltopt is significantly lower than that of G-Fedfilt which suggests that the optimized G-Fedfilt is also computationally efficient.

references:
Effect of Î¼ssubscriptğœ‡ğ‘ \mu_{s} Under Statistical Heterogeneity:
To have a full investigation on the tunable parameter Î¼ssubscriptğœ‡ğ‘ \mu_{s} and its behavior under data/label heterogeneity, we assess the performance of the proposed G-Fedfilt on i.i.d. dataset such as MNIST10, and Non-i.i.d. datasets including MNIST2, MNIST4, and EMNIST. Table 4 shows the classification accuracy (mean Â±plus-or-minus\pm standard deviation) of the proposed G-Fedfilt algorithm and FedAvg for K=20ğ¾20K=20 devices and after 200200200 communication rounds evaluated on the local test set. We observe that when the label and data heterogeneity is involved, G-Fedfilt achieves better accuracy than Fedavg, from 1.42%percent1.421.42\% for the EMNIST up to 6.12%percent6.126.12\% for the MNIST2 datasets; while for the MNIST10 where there is no heterogeneity, it does not perform superior to FedAvg on the local test set. It is also seen that increasing Î¼ssubscriptğœ‡ğ‘ \mu_{s} would reduce the accuracy since by doing so, higher frequencies are filtered. On the other hand, when looking at Table 5, which shows the resultant accuracy on the global test set, we see that imposing less personalization (by increasing Î¼ssubscriptğœ‡ğ‘ \mu_{s}) often eventuates in a better classification accuracy. This argument fairly applies to all the datasets. In addition, Table 6 shows the classification performance based on precision, recall, and F1-score. Here, the models are trained on the heterogeneous MNIST2 training dataset and tested on its local and global test sets. As seen, assigning a lower value to Î¼ssubscriptğœ‡ğ‘ \mu_{s} shows better performance on the local test set. On the other hand, the reduction in Î¼ssubscriptğœ‡ğ‘ \mu_{s} decreases the performance on the global test set in all three metrics. Based on the results in Tables 4, 5, and 6, it is rather concrete to say that there is a trade-off between model personalization and generalization in the G-Fedfilt aggregation rule that can be adjusted by the parameter Î¼ssubscriptğœ‡ğ‘ \mu_{s}.

Effect of Î¼ssubscriptğœ‡ğ‘ \mu_{s} Under Statistical Heterogeneity:
To have a full investigation on the tunable parameter Î¼ssubscriptğœ‡ğ‘ \mu_{s} and its behavior under data/label heterogeneity, we assess the performance of the proposed G-Fedfilt on i.i.d. dataset such as MNIST10, and Non-i.i.d. datasets including MNIST2, MNIST4, and EMNIST. Table 4 shows the classification accuracy (mean Â±plus-or-minus\pm standard deviation) of the proposed G-Fedfilt algorithm and FedAvg for K=20ğ¾20K=20 devices and after 200200200 communication rounds evaluated on the local test set. We observe that when the label and data heterogeneity is involved, G-Fedfilt achieves better accuracy than Fedavg, from 1.42%percent1.421.42\% for the EMNIST up to 6.12%percent6.126.12\% for the MNIST2 datasets; while for the MNIST10 where there is no heterogeneity, it does not perform superior to FedAvg on the local test set. It is also seen that increasing Î¼ssubscriptğœ‡ğ‘ \mu_{s} would reduce the accuracy since by doing so, higher frequencies are filtered. On the other hand, when looking at Table 5, which shows the resultant accuracy on the global test set, we see that imposing less personalization (by increasing Î¼ssubscriptğœ‡ğ‘ \mu_{s}) often eventuates in a better classification accuracy. This argument fairly applies to all the datasets. In addition, Table 6 shows the classification performance based on precision, recall, and F1-score. Here, the models are trained on the heterogeneous MNIST2 training dataset and tested on its local and global test sets. As seen, assigning a lower value to Î¼ssubscriptğœ‡ğ‘ \mu_{s} shows better performance on the local test set. On the other hand, the reduction in Î¼ssubscriptğœ‡ğ‘ \mu_{s} decreases the performance on the global test set in all three metrics. Based on the results in Tables 4, 5, and 6, it is rather concrete to say that there is a trade-off between model personalization and generalization in the G-Fedfilt aggregation rule that can be adjusted by the parameter Î¼ssubscriptğœ‡ğ‘ \mu_{s}.

Communication Desynchronization Alleviation:
In this simulation, we investigate the effect of dynamic values for Ïˆâ€‹(ğ’Ÿsi,cj;qsi,cj)ğœ“subscriptğ’Ÿsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—\psi(\mathcal{D}_{s_{i,c_{j}}};q_{s_{i,c_{j}}}) and Ï‡â€‹(Ï†â€‹(ğ’ˆsi,cj;zsi,cj))ğœ’ğœ‘subscriptğ’ˆsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğ‘§subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—\chi(\varphi(\boldsymbol{g}_{s_{i,c_{j}}};z_{s_{i,c_{j}}})) on the communication desynchronization and latency when the control parameters zsi,cjsubscriptğ‘§subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—z_{s_{i,c_{j}}}, qsi,cjsubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—q_{s_{i,c_{j}}}, and Î±si,cjsubscriptğ›¼subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—\alpha_{s_{i,c_{j}}} are optimized based on solving problem ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}. We set Î¼1=Î¼2=0.4subscriptğœ‡1subscriptğœ‡20.4\mu_{1}=\mu_{2}=0.4 and Î¼3=0.2subscriptğœ‡30.2\mu_{3}=0.2 for solving the optimization problem in the simulation where Î¼1+Î¼2+Î¼3=1subscriptğœ‡1subscriptğœ‡2subscriptğœ‡31\mu_{1}+\mu_{2}+\mu_{3}=1. Note that the reason for selecting a smaller Î¼3subscriptğœ‡3\mu_{3} lies behind the fact that it is experimentally shown in (Aji and Heafield, 2017), that almost 90%percent9090\% of the gradients to be sent to the server can be ignored with nearly no loss of classification accuracy. In addition, maximizing Ïˆâ€‹(ğ’Ÿsi,cj;qsi,cj)ğœ“subscriptğ’Ÿsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—\psi(\mathcal{D}_{s_{i,c_{j}}};q_{s_{i,c_{j}}}) and Î±si,cjsubscriptğ›¼subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—\alpha_{s_{i,c_{j}}} participate more to higher classification accuracy compared to that of zsi,cjsubscriptğ‘§subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—z_{s_{i,c_{j}}} which corresponds to decreasing the sparsification. We further opt to select bsi,cj=Î²Ksubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—ğ›½ğ¾b_{s_{i,c_{j}}}=\frac{\beta}{K}, qsi,cjmin=0.3superscriptsubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—min0.3q_{s_{i,c_{j}}}^{\textrm{min}}=0.3, Î±si,cjmin=1superscriptsubscriptğ›¼subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—min1\alpha_{s_{i,c_{j}}}^{\textrm{min}}=1, Î±si,cjmax=5superscriptsubscriptğ›¼subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—max5\alpha_{s_{i,c_{j}}}^{\textrm{max}}=5, and zsi,cjmin=0.1superscriptsubscriptğ‘§subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—min0.1z_{s_{i,c_{j}}}^{\textrm{min}}=0.1, âˆ€si,cjâˆˆğ’¦cjfor-allsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğ’¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘—\forall s_{i,c_{j}}\in\mathcal{K}_{c_{j}}, for simplicity and to have a minimum convergence requirement for the training process. Thus, after the optimization, the number of data samples for training and the sparsified gradients required to be sent to the server is obtained for each device. We determine different heterogeneous settings, indicated by Hğ»H, by producing random values for simulation parameters specified in Table 3. The performance of the proposed G-Fedfilt algorithm with Î¼s=10subscriptğœ‡ğ‘ 10\mu_{s}=10 is evaluated in Table 7 before and after the framework is optimized for different Hğ»H. Moreover, the models are trained on MNIST10 dataset and evaluated on its global test set. After 200200200 communication rounds, we can observe that there is a 99.63%percent99.6399.63\% and 47.91%percent47.9147.91\% reduction in the total communication desynchronization and latency when comparing G-FedfiltOpt with G-Fedfilt for H=0.31ğ»0.31H=0.31; although, it costs 2.14%percent2.142.14\% accuracy reduction. It is also seen that when Hğ»H increases, the desynchronization time and the latency are affected less for G-FedfiltOpt than that of G-Fedfilt; however, the accuracy decreases largely. One more important result that can be deduced in Table 7 is that when executing the algorithm for 400400400 communication rounds, the accuracy of G-FedfiltOpt increases at a faster pace than that of G-Fedfilt. This phenomenon is due to the fact that at each round of communication some devices with less computational capabilities train their models with the subset of the true dataset, i.e., ğ’Ÿ^si,cjâŠ†ğ’Ÿsi,cjsubscript^ğ’Ÿsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğ’Ÿsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—\widehat{\mathcal{D}}_{s_{i,c_{j}}}\subseteq\mathcal{D}_{s_{i,c_{j}}}. Thus, G-FedfiltOpt eventually achieves comparable accuracy to G-Fedfilt in the long run. It is worthwhile to note that a larger number of communication rounds does not mean a longer latency. For instance, we can see in Table 7 that G-FedfiltOpt achieves +1%percent1+1\% better accuracy than G-Fedfilt with the fairly similar latency, however, 200200200 more communication rounds. In addition, the bar graph in Fig. 9 shows the computation cost of this simulation under different heterogeneous settings and after 400400400 communication rounds. As observed, the cost of G-Fedfiltopt is significantly lower than that of G-Fedfilt which suggests that the optimized G-Fedfilt is also computationally efficient.
